confession.devil_appearance: appeared as small black bird when attacking Jean Regnauldin
confession.seduction_date: 14 years earlier (1597), when she was widow
confession.seduction_context: Widow with 3 small children, great difficulty feeding them during dearth. Persin promised to find her a rich husband
powder_types: red powder to kill people and animals
money which proved to be moss
sabbat_activities: cooking (did not make hail because busy cooking)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Price for keeping animals - husband wanted 17 gros a head, witness would not give 13 or 14

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: next day after she questioned nephew

testimony.quarrel_subject: Called her daughter 'fille de sorciere' after quarrel, mother complained furiously, his father beat him
testimony.threat_quote: there were things which deserved worse, and they would see 'd'autres farces'

testimony.quarrel_subject: Quarrel with her husband over spring they both claimed

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: some remained ill for 2 weeks, others for 6

testimony.quarrel_subject: Collecting tithe, her husband left miserably small sheaf in field of rye
testimony.threat_quote: que c'estoient bien des autres nouvelles, et que se n'avoit doncq pas faict Jean Sagaire qui les avoit faict mourir

testimony.quarrel_subject: Refused to lend cart to move wood because he needed it himself

witnesses.name: Hellaine femme Didier Claudon Noel
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: husband deposed against her at first trial

testimony.quarrel_subject: Same as husband - argument over tithe
Husband elected to make monthly levy, accused protested angrily when assessed at 2 blancs each month
testimony.threat_quote: threatening to make witness and husband feel it

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: found on two occasions baby had fallen out of cradle

testimony.quarrel_subject: Asked witness to take in animals when returning from reaping, angry when refused

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: same day - fell and child fell face downwards
same day - wolf attacked cow, tearing away large part of leg

testimony.quarrel_subject: Husband refused to lend cart to husband of accused; daughter Agathe in their service, accused wanted her to make pilgrimage while husband looked after animals, very angry when refused

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: sickened same day, died next day

testimony.quarrel_subject: Same as husband - dispute over spring
Daughter of accused beat her daughter while guarding animals, then husband gave the girl a blow on head
Jean Regnauldin had dispute with her, she told witness in church saying he would repent

Multiple quarrels: (1) monthly levy 7 years earlier; (2) refused to renew daughter Collatte as servant at Christmas 12 years earlier; (3) 14 years earlier when widow, asked him to arrange Georgeon Claudon Noel as her 'fassens' on 'jour des Brandons', promising 3 cakes of 9 gros each, but he persuaded companions not to do it

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: soon after she went into house (after refusal to renew servant)
2 days later after 'fassenatz' incident - whirlwind made him fall while cutting oak branches, foot caught, small black bird tried to peck him

testimony.quarrel_subject: Asked him to make cloth, left in fury when he said could not make it as soon as she wanted due to other orders

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: that evening - felt great weight on him in bed, almost as if wall had fallen, recovered after making sign of cross with tongue

testimony.quarrel_subject: Threshing with her husband, quarrel over some small matter
testimony.threat_quote: said in several places that he would repent

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 2 or 3 days later - became strangely ill, remained so for 14 weeks

testimony.quarrel_subject: 3 piglets escaped and passed in front of her house
testimony.threat_quote: wishing the devil might have his soul and that of his pig

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: immediately became black as coal and swollen, then died
few days later - gave it grass from garden near her house, died within minutes

timeline.subject: Jennon la Mouratte
timeline.details: Renvoyée (released) from first trial on advice of Change de Nancy after resisting torture

timeline.subject: Jennon la Mouratte
timeline.details: Interrogation and confrontations with witnesses; denied all charges, refused to renounce devil

timeline.subject: Jennon la Mouratte
timeline.details: Confronted with witnesses; no reproaches, continued denials

timeline.subject: Jennon la Mouratte
timeline.details: Procureur for abbot of Etival asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Jennon la Mouratte
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture - thumbscrews and rack (half turn only); confessed after being set down by fire

timeline.subject: Jennon la Mouratte
timeline.details: Repeated confessions, provided moral reflections on witchcraft and melancholy

timeline.subject: Jennon la Mouratte
timeline.details: Brought before bourgeois of Etival, confessions read out and confirmed, left to will of duke for execution; procureur asked for death sentence, approved by Change de Nancy (date missing)

torture.restrictions: Face became black during racking, judged that devil was preventing her feeling anything

accomplices_named.name: Jean Sagaire
accomplices_named.context: Named during confession as accomplice, 'les plus meschans de tous'

accomplices_named.name: Ysabel femme Mengeon Jean Dieudonné
accomplices_named.context: Named during confession as accomplice; tried with her 12 years earlier

accomplices_named.name: Claudon Mathelon
accomplices_named.context: Named during confession as accomplice, 'les plus meschans de tous'

prior_accusations.context: Accused by other condemned witches, leading to first trial in 1599

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon la Mouratte
notable_quotes.french: elle est contante qu'on la fasse mourrir, qu'elle nous pardonne sa mort, et ne dira jamais autrement quelz tourmentz que luy deussions faire endurer
notable_quotes.english: she is content that they put her to death, that she pardons them her death, and will never say otherwise whatever torments they should make her endure
notable_quotes.context: During initial interrogation when asked about accusations

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon la Mouratte
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle n'est de telles gens pour faire mourrir des personnes et des bestiaulx, et que jamais elle ne pardonnera ledit Didier de la charge qu'il luy impose
notable_quotes.english: she is not the sort of person to kill people and animals, and that she will never pardon Didier for the charge he imposes on her
notable_quotes.context: Response to accusation about killing Didier Claudon Noel's animals

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon la Mouratte
notable_quotes.french: que c'estoient bien des autres nouvelles, et que se n'avoit doncq pas faict Jean Sagaire qui les avoit faict mourir
notable_quotes.english: that these were quite other news, and if it was not Jean Sagaire who had made them die
notable_quotes.context: Her response when Didier accused her of killing his animals

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon la Mouratte
notable_quotes.french: et la sollicitoit tousjours de faire du mal, que c'est moult grand pitié d'une pauvre creature qui delaisse Dieu pour s'addonner au diable, au contraire sont bien heureux qui ont bonne fiance a Dieu et le servent comme il appartient, et sur tout ne fault oblier soir et matin se recommander a Dieu et se munir du signe de la Croix, et fault eviter les tristesse et melancolie le plus que possible sera, car la tristesse et melancolie sont estez causes de sa tentation
notable_quotes.english: and he always solicited her to do evil, that it is very great pity for a poor creature who forsakes God to give herself to the devil, on the contrary those are very happy who have good faith in God and serve him as is proper, and above all one must not forget morning and evening to commend oneself to God and arm oneself with the sign of the Cross, and one must avoid sadness and melancholy as much as possible, for sadness and melancholy were the causes of her temptation
notable_quotes.context: Moral reflections during confession on April 8, 1611

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacquot Claudon Noel (witness 20)
notable_quotes.french: que le diable puisse avoir son âme et celle de son cochon
notable_quotes.english: may the devil have his soul and that of his pig
notable_quotes.context: Jennon's response when accused of killing piglet

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon la Mouratte (witness 2 testimony)
notable_quotes.context: Threat to witness 2 after his father beat him

relationships.evidence_text: Jennon la Mouratte, femme Bertremin de Laval
daughter of late Nicolas Mourel of Nompatelize
her niece Collatte, fille feu Blaise Fontaine of Biarville
her daughter Colatte had been servant to late Jean Regnauldin his father
sent animals out in keeping of nephew

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over economic resources: pricing for animal keeping (witness 1), tithe collection (witness 4), cart lending (witnesses 5, 10, 16), monthly levy assessment (witness 7), payment for hoeing (confession). Accused described as widow with 3 small children having 'great difficulty feeding them in dearth then prevailing' at time of seduction. Her niece complained that late husband had 'sold and wasted all her property as her guardian'. Soldiers billeted on her (mentioned in confession).

material_culture.context: Multiple witnesses mention lending or refusing to lend carts (witnesses 5, 10, 15, 16)
Dispute over miserably small sheaf left in field (witness 4)
Price per head for keeping animals (witness 1)
Baby aged 6 months fell out of cradle (witness 7)
Asked Nicolas Cariolle (tixerant/weaver) to make cloth (witness 17)
Cooked in water with powder to poison niece (confession)
Given by devil to kill people and animals (confession)

material_culture.object: money which proved to be moss

material_culture.context: Torture instrument, given half turn (torture session)
Musical instrument at sabbat - danced to sound of 'violeur' (confession)
Water source disputed between Girard Toussainct and accused's husband (witness 3)

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial, residence of accused and most witnesses
Location of witness 5 (Georgeon Claudon Noel, moictrier)
Court jurisdiction - procureur for abbot of Etival; Mr d'Etival mentioned; brought before bourgeois of Etival
Location of Change de Nancy (appellate court); accused requested response be sent 'a Nancy aux eschevins'

spatial_references.place_name: la Chapelle d'Urtimont, near St Dié

spatial_references.context: Sabbat location mentioned in confession - been more than 20 times
Sabbat location mentioned in confession - been more than 20 times
Origin of niece Collatte fille feu Blaise Fontaine
Location of Jean Mareschal (ermite de Boullain) named as accomplice
Location of Jean Claude Mathieu named as accomplice
Location of Claudon Mathelon and Marguitte veuve Jean Laurent named as accomplices
Location of Jennon femme Claudon Girard and Marguitte femme Nicolas Jeandey named as accomplices
Location of Esnel femme Demenge Bourrotte named as accomplice
Multiple mentions: moving wood (witness 5), cutting oak branches (witness 15), following cart to woods (witness 15)
Field of rye for tithe (witness 4), leaving field at harvest (witness 9)
Witness 5 saw her in garden; witness 7 went to garden; witness 20 had garden near her house
Witness 13 spoke with accused in church on Sunday
Accused went to edge of ditch intending to drown herself after killing her own cow (confession)

historical_context.military_details: Soldiers billeted on accused - mentioned in confession as context for killing Nicolas de Boullain who did not help her when soldiers were billeted on her
weather_events: whirlwind (witness 15 - caused Jean Regnauldin to fall from tree)
animal_predation: wolf passed through herd and attacked cow of witness 9, tearing away large part of leg
economic_hardship_indicators: dearth prevailing when accused was widowed with 3 small children, had great difficulty feeding them (confession)
disputes over small amounts: 2 blancs monthly levy, pricing for animal keeping, miserably small tithe sheaf, payment for hoeing
niece complained that guardian sold and wasted all her property
religious_calendar_references: Christmas - time when accused wanted to renew daughter as servant (witness 15)
jour des Brandons - when 'fassenatz' were given, accused wanted Georgeon Claudon Noel as her 'fassens' (witness 15)

prior_legal_disputes.description: Didier Claudon Noel called her witch 2 years earlier, accusing her of making all his animals ill, threatening to kill her or have her burned. Neither she nor husband sought any reparation for this (witness 14)
Georgeon Claudon Noel accused her of being witch and causing death of cow, husband threatened to take him before Mr d'Etival but never did (witness 5)
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Threat made but not carried out

prior_legal_disputes.description: Jacquot Claudon Noel accused her of being witch and killing piglet (witness 20)

legal_context.redress_outcome: Multiple witnesses called her witch publicly without her seeking legal redress
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Persin came to prison previous night before torture and promised she should die when racked (confession)

change_de_nancy.modification_details: Approved torture on March 23, 1611; approved death sentence (date missing)

hearsay_chains.source: heard from loft where he had hidden
hearsay_chains.content: Heard mother's threats 'd'autres farces' from loft
Told witness about dispute, witness then told Jean Regnauldin about threats, he lost ox

emotional_state_notes: Initially defiant and resigned: 'she is content that they put her to death, that she pardons them her death'
Refused to renounce devil during initial interrogation
Angry at Didier Claudon Noel: 'will never pardon him'
After torture, expressed remorse and gave moral warnings about melancholy and witchcraft
Begged abbot and bourgeois to have pity on her poor children

third_parties.name: Colatte
third_parties.context: Served as servant to Jean Regnauldin's late father, witness 2 called her 'fille de sorciere'

third_parties.name: Agathe
third_parties.context: In service to Symon de Besmont, accused wanted her to make pilgrimage (witness 10)

third_parties.name: Collatte fille feu Blaise Fontaine
third_parties.context: Died a week after accused gave her poisoned pears (confession)

third_parties.name: Blaise Fontaine
third_parties.relationship_to_accused: brother (inferred - was Collatte's uncle via marriage)
third_parties.context: Late husband/guardian who sold and wasted niece's property

third_parties.name: Jean Sagaire
third_parties.context: Accused mentioned his name when denying killing Didier's animals; later named him as accomplice 'les plus meschans de tous'

third_parties.name: Marion femme Georgeon Colas Noel
third_parties.context: Confessed to killing her because she did not pay properly for hoeing

third_parties.name: Nicolas de Boullain
third_parties.context: Confessed to killing him because he did not help when she had soldiers billeted on her

third_parties.name: Claudon son of Maurizatte veuve Jean de la Chambre
third_parties.context: Confessed to killing him after quarrel with his mother; had been accused of this at first trial

third_parties.name: Maurizatte veuve Jean de la Chambre
third_parties.context: Mother of Claudon whom accused allegedly killed

third_parties.name: Jean Regnauldin (late father)
third_parties.context: Colatte served as his servant; beat his son for calling her 'fille de sorciere'; lost animals attributed to accused's witchcraft

third_parties.name: nephew of Mengeon Claudon Noel
third_parties.context: Sent to keep animals, accused questioned him about cows

third_parties.name: Georgeon Claudon Noel (fassens incident)
third_parties.context: 14 years earlier when widow, she wanted him as her 'fassens' on 'jour des Brandons' but Jean Regnauldin persuaded companions not to do it

extraction_metadata.notes: Second trial for same person - first trial in 1599 resulted in release (renvoyée) after resisting torture on advice of Change de Nancy. Strong pattern of quarrels over economic resources (animal keeping, tithe, cart lending, payment disputes) followed by animal deaths/illnesses. Confession obtained under torture (thumbscrews and rack). Notable for moral reflections in confession about melancholy as cause of temptation. Named 10 living accomplices. Some temporal references given as 'years earlier' - specific dates calculated backward from 1611 trial date.
